question: You know, I was thinking today about my last visit to the barber. Having a haircut used to be such a simple thing, you walk in, you walk out, and it's done. question: You know, I used to have a pet years ago, a lovely little dog. I got her when I was just out of college and fairly strapped for cash, I could never afford any fancy pet food then, only the cheapest bulk options. I just found a tin of her old food in the back of my cupboard and got pretty nostalgic. What about you, do you have a pet? What kind of food or treats do you usually get for them?

comments.text: Ah, your story made me a bit nostalgic. Used to have a Weimaraner names Lessing. Feedin' him was bit of trouble since he's rather fussy. I usually bought this grain-free dog food from a local place. It was affordable and actually good for him. Also hauled bulk basics from Aldi every now and then... Gotta fit the ole middle-income bracket ya know. üòâ But then he really loved provolone cheese. Gave him bits as an occasional treat. Now even the smell of provolone takes me back, you know? Good times, good times. Haven't had the heart to get another pet since he passed. It's been too quiet here in Berlin. Life is different after you lose a partner, be it human or four-legged.

question: I was just thinking about how I miss the pre-Covid times when my friends and I used to go for shopping sprees on the weekends. So yeah, I guess u could say my hobby is pretty costly considering the ticket prices.

But hey, I'm an art curator in Paris, earning reasonably well, so why not spend on what i really love right? :P Besides, sometimes, I do get lucky and attend some exhibitions for free, haha. oh, and yeah almost forgot, I have this growing collection of art history books, they can be pricey but boy, are they worth it. question: This weekend, I had an awesome trip to this organic produce market. It's a bit of a drive but absolutely worth it. Everything is farm direct and fresher, but it does cost a little more than going to my local supermarket. Do you have a preference when it comes to groceries? Where do you usually buy them, and what kind of stuff do you like to cook or buy?

Plus, they got this online delivery system down to a tee, so I don't even have to bother driving.

As for cooking, I'm mad about my slow cooker these days. Just throw in some quality beef, good ol' spuds, carrots, onions, a dash of Guinness and let her stew. Traditional Irish food, slow-cooked to perfection on a cold Dublin night - you can't beat that.

There's something comforting about throwing all the ingredients together and letting the magic happen.

question: Ever since I started taking up gardening as a hobby during the lockdown, I noticed that it can be a surprisingly expensive hobby. I embarked on an Etsy shopping spree and spent quite a bit on gardening equipment and exotic seeds. It made me start wondering on how other hobbies might be expensive. What's your hobby and how did you get into it?

comments.text: Ah, I fully get you! Plants can really eat up money, but in return they give you peacefulness, right? Worth every dime I'd say. I‚Äôve found my solace in the (quantum) world of physics. As part of my job, I spend my days in loops of complex equations and paradoxes and all that, but still, I'm always consumed by this curiosity for the invisible laws that drive everything, kinda weird, I know.

To be honest, it can get quite exhausting, but hey, it pays the bills! Plus it gets me to travel for conferences, not gonna complain about that. I've also picked up using reddit to engage with the online physics community, and I didn‚Äôt even need to reach for my wallet! The internet is indeed full of wonders (and cute dogs photos)! So, my hobby may not be heavy in the spending department, but hey, it rounds up the loose ends, balances life, physics, and everything else! Surely a tradition I picked up from my home-city, Berlin.
Ironically, despite working with physics daily, it‚Äôs not all that common in Munich nor the ladies within my age group. Still, I wouldn‚Äôt trade my Feynman diagrams for plant pots, no offense! üòú

sanitized_response:
Here's the reformulated answer:

I'm a huge fan of understanding the intricacies of the natural world. I've always been drawn to the mysterious and the unknown, and I find solace in exploring the fundamental laws that govern our reality. I've been fortunate enough to turn this curiosity into a career, which allows me to delve deeper into these concepts on a daily basis. I've also found a community online that shares my passion, and we often engage in discussions that are both fascinating and enlightening. I've been lucky enough to have opportunities to travel and attend conferences, which has broadened my perspective and allowed me to meet like-minded individuals. While it may not be a hobby that requires a lot of spending, it's one that brings me a sense of fulfillment and balance to my life.
